original: taccakṣuḥ puruṣo yena svapne paśyatiityādyā ca śrutiḥ /
analyzed: tat cakṣuḥ puruṣaḥ yena svapne paśyati ityādyā ca śrutiḥ
translated: And the Vedic text: That eye with which one sees in a dream and so on.

analyzed: nityā ātmanaḥ dṛṣṭiḥ bāhya anitya dṛṣṭeḥ grāhikā
translated: The vision of the Self is eternal, and it perceives the external non-eternal vision.

analyzed: bāhya dṛṣṭeḥ ca upajana apāya ādya anitya dharmavat tvāt tad grāhikāyāḥ ātma dṛṣṭeḥ tadvat avabhāsa tvam anitya tva ādi bhrānti nimittam lokasya iti yuktam
translated: And because the external vision has the properties of arising, perishing, etc., which are non-eternal, it is proper for the world to think that the vision of the Self which perceives that has the same appearance of non-eternality, etc., as the cause of error.

analyzed: yathā bhramaṇa ādi dharma vat alāta ādi vastu viṣaya dṛṣṭiḥ api bhramati iva tadvat
translated: Just as the vision of the object such as a whirling fire-brand, which has the property of whirling, etc., also appears to whirl.

analyzed: tathā ca śrutiḥ dhyāyati iva lelāyati iva bṛu
translated: And thus the Vedic text: Meditating as it were, moving as it were (Br. 3.9.26).

analyzed: tasmāt ātma dṛṣṭeḥ nitya tvāt na yaugapadyam ayaugapadyam vā asti
translated: Therefore, because the vision of the Self is eternal, there is neither simultaneity nor non-simultaneity.

original: bāhyānityadṛṣṭyupādhivaśāttu lokasya tārkikāṇāṃ cāgamasaṃpradāyavarjitatvād anityā ātmano dṛṣṭiriti bhrāntirupapannaiva /
analyzed: bāhya anitya dṛṣṭi upādhi vaśāt tu lokasya tārkikāṇām ca āgama saṃpradāya varjita tvāt anityā ātmanaḥ dṛṣṭiḥ iti bhrāntiḥ upapannā eva
translated: But because of the limiting adjunct of the external non-eternal vision, and because the world and the logicians are devoid of the tradition of the scriptures, the error arises that the vision of the Self is non-eternal.

analyzed: jīva īśvara paramātma bheda kalpanā ca etad nimittā eva
translated: And the conception of the difference between the individual soul, the Lord, and the supreme Self is based on this.

original: tathā ca asti nāstītyādyāśca yāvanto vāṅmanasayorbhedā yatraikaṃ bhavanti /
analyzed: tathā ca asti na asti ityādyāḥ ca yāvantaḥ vāc manasayoḥ bhedāḥ yatra ekam bhavanti
translated: And thus, all the distinctions of speech and mind, such as exists, does not exist, etc., which occur there,

analyzed: tad viṣayāyāḥ nityāyāḥ dṛṣṭeḥ nirviśeṣāyāḥ asti na asti
translated: Of that, of the eternal vision which is free from distinctions, there is neither existence nor non-existence.

analyzed: ekam nānā
translated: One or many.

analyzed: guṇavat aguṇam
translated: With qualities or without qualities.

analyzed: jānāti na jānāti
translated: Knows or does not know.

analyzed: kriyāvat akriyam phalavat aphalam
translated: With action or without action, with fruit or without fruit.

analyzed: sa bījam nirbījam
translated: With seed or without seed.

analyzed: sukham duḥkham
translated: Happiness or sorrow.

analyzed: madhyama madhyam
translated: Medium or not medium.

analyzed: śūnyam a śūnyam
translated: Empty or not empty.

original: paro 'hamanya iti vā saravavākpratyayāgocare svarūpe yo vikalpayitumicchati /
analyzed: paras hamanyaḥ iti vā sa rava vāc pratyaya agocare svarūpe yaḥ vikalpayitum icchati
translated: He who wishes to conceptualize in the nature that is beyond the sphere of all verbal expressions, such as I am different or I am another,

analyzed: sa nūnam khamati carma vat veṣṭayitum icchati
translated: he certainly wishes to wrap it like a piece of leather.

original: sopānamiva ca padbhyāmāroḍhum jale khe ca mīnānāṃ vayasāṃ ca padaṃ didṛkṣate /
analyzed: sopānam iva ca padbhyām āroḍhum jale khe ca mīnānām vayasām ca padam didṛkṣate
translated: And he wishes to climb it with his feet like a staircase, and he desires to see the footprints of fish and birds in water and space.

analyzed: na iti na iti bṛu
translated: Not so, not so (Br. Up. 4.5.15).

analyzed: yatas vācaḥ nivartante itaiḥ
translated: From which words turn back (Tai. Up. 2.4).

analyzed: ityādi śrutibhyaḥ
translated: Thus it is stated in the Upanishads.

analyzed: kaḥ addhā vedaṛsam
translated: Who indeed knows (Rg. Veda 10.129.6).

original: ityādimantravarṇāt /🔽kathaṃ tarhi tasya sa ma ātmeti vedanam /
analyzed: ityādi mantra varṇāt  katham tarhi tasya sa me ātmā iti vedanam
translated: Thus it is stated in the mantras.🔽How then is the knowledge That is my Self?

original: brūhi kena prakāreṇa tamahaṃ sa ma ātmeti vidyām /
analyzed: brūhi kena prakāreṇa tam aham sa me ātmā iti vidyām
translated: Tell me by what means I may know That is my Self.

original: atrākhyāyikāmācakṣate kaścitkila manuṣyo mugdhaḥ kaiściduktaḥ kasmiṃścidaparādhe sati dhiktvāṃ nāsi manuṣya iti /
analyzed: atra ākhyāyikām ācakṣate kaścid kila manuṣyaḥ mugdhaḥ kaiścid uktaḥ kasmiṃścid aparādhe sati dhik tvām na asi manuṣyaḥ iti
translated: Regarding this, some say that a certain foolish man was told by some people, Shame on you! You are not a human being, when he had committed some offense.

original: sa mugdhatayā ātmano manuṣyatvaṃ pratyāyayituṃ kañcidupetyāha bravītu bhavānko 'hamasmīti /
analyzed: sa mugdha tayā ātmanaḥ manuṣya tvam pratyāyayitum kañcid upetya āha bravītu bhavān kaḥ ham asmi iti
translated: Out of foolishness, in order to prove his own humanity, he approached someone and said, Tell me, who am I?

analyzed: sa tasya mugdha tām jñātvā āha
translated: That person, knowing his foolishness, said,

analyzed: krameṇa bodhayiṣyāmi iti
translated: I will teach you gradually.

analyzed: sthāvara ādi ātma bhāvam apohya na tvam amanuṣyaḥ iti uktvā upararāma
translated: Having removed the idea of his body being an inanimate object, he said, You are not a non-human being, and stopped.

original: sa taṃ mugdhaḥ pratyāha bhavānmāṃ bodhayituṃ pravṛttastūṣṇīṃ babhūva /
analyzed: sa tam mugdhaḥ pratyāha bhavān mām bodhayitum pravṛttaḥ tūṣṇīm babhūva
translated: That foolish man replied to him, You started to teach me, but you remained silent.

analyzed: kim na bodhayati iti
translated: Why don't you teach me?

original: tādṛgeva tadbhavito vacanam /🔽nāsyamanuṣya ityukte 'pi manuṣyatvamātmano na pratipadyate yaḥ sa kathaṃ manuṣyo 'sītyukto 'pi manuṣyatvamātmanaḥ pratipadyeta tasmādyathāśāstropadeśa
analyzed: tādṛś eva tat bhavitaḥ vacanam  na asya amanuṣyaḥ iti ukte manuṣya tvam ātmanaḥ na pratipadyate yaḥ sa katham manuṣyaḥ asi iti uktaḥ manuṣya tvam ātmanaḥ pratipadyeta tasmāt yathā śāstra upadeśa
translated: That statement would be just like that.

analyzed: eva ātma avabodha vidhiḥ na anyaḥ
translated: How could one who, even when told You are not a non-human being, does not understand his own humanity, understand his own humanity when told You are a human being? Therefore, the method of understanding the self is only as taught in the scriptures, not otherwise.

analyzed: na hi agneḥ dāhyam tṛṇa ādi anyena kenacid dgdhum śakyam
translated: For the fuel to be burned by fire cannot be burned by anything else.

original: ata eva śāstramātmasvarūpaṃ bodhayituṃ pravṛttaṃ sadamanuṣyatvapratiṣedhenevaneti neti
analyzed: atas eva śāstram ātma svarūpam bodhayitum pravṛttam na iti
translated: Therefore, the scripture, engaged in revealing the nature of the self, ceased after saying Not so, not so, as if forbidding even humanness.

analyzed: iti uktvā upararāma  tathā ananta
translated: Thus, Not so, not so, etc.

analyzed: ayam ātmā brahma sarva anubhūḥ bṛu
translated: This self is Brahman, the experiencer of all.

analyzed: iti anuśāsanam  tattvam asi chau
translated: This is the teaching.🔽That thou art.

analyzed: yatra tu asya sarvam ātmā eva abhūt tat kena kam paśyet bṛhat
translated: Wherein all this becomes the self alone, by whom and whom should one see? Not so, not so, etc.

analyzed: iti evamādi api ca
translated: And so on.

analyzed: yāvat ayam evam yathoktam imam ātmānam na vetti tāvat ayam bāhya anitya dṛṣṭi lakṣaṇam upādhim ātma tvena upetya
translated: As long as one does not know this self as described, as long as one identifies with the limiting adjunct characterized by external impermanence,

analyzed: avidyayā upādhi dharmān ātmanaḥ manyamānaḥ brahma ādi stamba paryanteṣu deva tiryak nara sthāneṣu
translated: conceiving the attributes of the limiting adjunct to be one's own due to ignorance, one transmigrates again and again in the realms of gods, animals, and humans, from Brahmā down to a blade of grass,

analyzed: punar punar āvartamānaḥ vidyā kāma karma vaśāt saṃsarati
translated: wandering due to the power of ignorance, desire, and action.

original: sa evaṃ punarevameva nadīsrotovajjanmamaraṇaprabandhāvicchedena vartamānaḥ kābhiravasthābhirvartata ityetamarthaṃ darśayantyāha śrutirvairāgyahetoḥ
analyzed: saḥ evam punar evam eva nadī srotaḥ vat janma maraṇa prabandha avicchedena vartamānaḥ kābhiḥ avasthābhiḥ vartate iti etam artham darśayantī āha śrutiḥ vairāgya hetoḥ
translated: Thus, continuing in this way, like the current of a river, without interruption in the series of birth and death, in what states does one exist? To show this meaning, the scripture says for the sake of detachment:

original: puruṣe ha vā ayam ādito garbho bhavati yad etad retaḥ /
analyzed: puruṣe ha vai ayam āditas garbhaḥ bhavati yat etat retaḥ
translated: In a man, this embryo is at first this semen.

original: tad etat sarvebhyo 'ṅgebhyas tejaḥ sambhūtam ātmany evātmānaṃ bibharti /
analyzed: tat etat sarvebhyaḥ ṅgebhyaḥ tejaḥ sambhūtam ātmani eva ātmānam bibharti
translated: This, arisen from the essence of all the limbs, he bears the self in the self itself.

original: tad yadā striyāṃ siñcaty athainaj janayati /
analyzed: tat yadā striyām siñcati atha enat janayati
translated: When he emits it into a woman, then he generates it.

analyzed: tat asya prathamam janma
translated: That is his first birth.

original: ayamevāvidyākāmakarmābhimānavān yajñādikarma kṛtvāsmāllokād dhūmādikrameṇa annabhūtaḥ puruṣāgnau hutaḥ /
analyzed: ayam eva avidyā kāma karma abhimānavān yajña ādi karma kṛtvā asmāt lokāt dhūma ādi krameṇa anna bhūtaḥ puruṣa agnau hutaḥ
translated: This very one, identified with ignorance, desire, and action, having performed actions such as sacrifices, is offered as food from this world in the fire of the Purusha in the sequence beginning with smoke.

original: tasminpuruṣe ha vā ayaṃ saṃsārī rasādikrameṇa āditaḥ prathamato retorūpeṇa garbho bhavatītyetadāha yadetatpuruṣe retastena rūpeṇeti /
analyzed: tasmin puruṣe ha vai ayam saṃsārī rasa ādi krameṇa āditas prathamatas retaḥ rūpeṇa garbhaḥ bhavati iti etat āha yat etat puruṣe retaḥ tena rūpeṇa iti
translated: In that Purusha, this transmigrating one becomes an embryo in the form of semen in the beginning, at first, in the sequence beginning with rasa, it is said that this is the embryo in the form of semen in the Purusha.

original: taccaitadreto 'nnamayasya piṇḍasya sarvebhyo 'ṅgebhyo 'vayavebhyo rasādilakṣaṇebhyastejaḥ sārarūpaṃ śarīrasya saṃbhūtaṃ pariniṣpannaṃ tatpuruṣasyātmabhūtatvādātmā
analyzed: tat ca etat retaḥ nna mayasya piṇḍasya sarvebhyaḥ ṅgebhyaḥ vayavebhyaḥ rasa ādi lakṣaṇebhyaḥ tejaḥ sāra rūpam śarīrasya saṃbhūtam pariniṣpannam tatpuruṣasya ātma bhūta tvāt ātmā
translated: And that semen, the essence in the form of heat, arisen from all the limbs, from all the parts characterized by rasa etc., of the lump consisting of food, is fully accomplished. That self

original: tamātmānaṃ retorūpeṇa garbhībhūtamātmanyeva svaśarīra evātmānaṃ bibharti dhārayati /
analyzed: tam ātmānam retaḥ rūpeṇa garbhībhūtam ātmani eva sva śarīre eva ātmānam bibharti dhārayati
translated: he bears that self in the form of semen in his own body, in himself alone. He sustains it.

original: tadreto yadā yasminkāle bhāryartumatī tasyāṃ yoṣāgnau striyā siñcatyugacchan /
analyzed: tat retaḥ yadā yasmin kāle bhāryā ṛtumatī tasyām yoṣā agnau striyā siñcati ugacchan
translated: That semen, when it is emitted, when the husband has intercourse with his wife, in her, in the woman, as in a fire.

original: atha tadainadetadreta ātmano garbhabhūtaṃ janayati pitā /
analyzed: atha tadā enat etat retaḥ ātmanaḥ garbha bhūtam janayati pitā
translated: Then that semen, which is the self in the embryo, the father generates it.

original: tadasya puruṣasya sthānānnirgamanaṃ retaḥsekakāle retorūreṇāsya saṃsāriṇaḥ prathamaṃ janma prathamāvasthābhivyaktiḥ /
analyzed: tat asya puruṣasya sthānāt nirgamanam retaḥ seka kāle retaḥ rūreṇa asya saṃsāriṇaḥ prathamam janma prathama avasthā abhivyaktiḥ
translated: That is the first birth, the first manifestation of the state, of this transmigrating person, the emission of semen at the time of emission.

analyzed: tat etat uktam purastāt asau ātmā amum ātmānam ityādinā
translated: This has been said before, That Self which is free from evil and so on.

original: tat striyā ātmabhūyaṃ gacchati yathā svam aṅgaṃ tathā /
analyzed: tat striyāḥ ātma bhūyam gacchati yathā svam aṅgam tathā
translated: That semen goes to the state of oneness with the woman, just as with one's own limb.

analyzed: tasmāt enām na hinasti
translated: Therefore, he does not harm her.

analyzed: sā asya etam ātmānam atra gatam bhāvayati
translated: She nourishes that self of his which has gone there.

original: tadreto yasyāṃ striyāṃ siktaṃ sattasyā ātmabhūyamātmāvyatirekatāṃ yathā piturevaṃ gacchati prāpnoti yathā svamaṅgaṃ stanādi tathā tadvadeva
analyzed: tat retaḥ yasyām striyām siktam sat tasyāḥ ātma bhūyam ātma avyatireka tām yathā pituḥ evam gacchati prāpnoti yathā svam aṅgam stana ādi tathā tadvat eva
translated: That semen, when emitted into a woman, goes to the state of oneness with her, of non-difference from her, just as with the father. Just as with his own limb, such as the breast, so it is like that.

original: tasmāddhetorenāṃ mātaraṃ sa garbho na hinasti piṭakādivat /
analyzed: tasmāt hetoḥ enām mātaram sa garbhaḥ na hinasti piṭaka ādi vat
translated: For this reason, that embryo does not harm the mother, like a boil and so on.

original: yasmātstanādi svāṅgavadātmabhūtaṃ gataṃ tasmānna hinasti na bādhata ityarthaḥ /🔽sā antarvatnyetamasya bharturātmānamatrātmana udare gataṃ praviṣṭaṃ buddhvā bhāvayati vardhayati paripālayati garbhaviruddhāśanādiparihāramanukūlāśanādyupayogaṃ
analyzed: yasmāt stana ādi sva aṅga vat ātma bhūtam gatam tasmāt na hinasti na bādhate iti arthaḥ  sā antarvatnī etam asya bhartuḥ ātmānam atra ātmanaḥ udare gatam praviṣṭam buddhvā bhāvayati vardhayati paripālayati garbha viruddha aśana ādi parihāram anukūla aśana ādi upayogam
translated: Because the breast, etc. have become like one's own body, part of oneself, therefore it does not injure, i.e. does not obstruct.

analyzed: ca kurvatī
translated: She, being pregnant, having understood that this self of her husband has entered, has gone into her own belly, nourishes, increases, protects it, by avoiding food, etc. that are harmful to the fetus, and by using food, etc. that are favorable.

analyzed: sā bhāvayitrī bhāvayitavyā bhavati
translated: She who nourishes is to be nourished.

original: taṃ strī garbhaṃ bibharti /🔽so 'gra eva kumāraṃ janmano 'gre 'dhi bhāvayati /
analyzed: tam strī garbham bibharti  saḥ gre eva kumāram janmanaḥ gre dhi bhāvayati
translated: That woman carries the fetus.🔽He, at the very beginning, nourishes the child before birth.

original: sa yat kumāraṃ janmano 'gre 'dhi bhāvayaty ātmānam eva tad bhāvayaty eṣāṃ lokānāṃ santatyai /
analyzed: sa yat kumāram janmanaḥ gre dhi bhāvayati ātmānam eva tat bhāvayati eṣām lokānām santatyai
translated: In that he nourishes the child before birth, he nourishes himself for the continuity of these worlds.

analyzed: evam santatāḥ hi ime lokāḥ
translated: For these worlds are indeed continuous in this way.

analyzed: tat asya dvitīyam janma
translated: That is his second birth.

original: sā bhāvayitrī vardhayitrī bharturātmano garbhabhūtasya bhāvayitavyā vardhayitavyā rakṣayitavyā ca bhartā bhavati /
analyzed: sā bhāvayitrī vardhayitrī bhartuḥ ātmanaḥ garbha bhūtasya bhāvayitavyā vardhayitavyā rakṣayitavyā ca bhartā bhavati
translated: She who nourishes, who increases, is to be nourished, to be increased, to be protected by her husband, who is in the form of a fetus. The husband becomes so.

analyzed: na hi upakāra pratyupakāram antareṇa loke kasyacid kenacid sambandhaḥ upapadyate
translated: For in the world, no connection between anyone and anything is possible without benefit and return benefit.

original: taṃ garbhaṃ strī yathoktena garbhadhāraṇavidhānena bibharti dhārayatyagre prāgjanmanaḥ /🔽sa pitā agra eva pūrvameva jātamātraṃ janmano 'dhyūrdhvaṃ janmano jātaṃ kumāraṃ jātakarmādinā pitā bhāvayati /
analyzed: tam garbham strī yathā uktena garbha dhāraṇa vidhānena bibharti dhārayati agre prāc janmanaḥ  sa pitā agre eva pūrvam eva jāta mātram janmanaḥ dhi ūrdhvam janmanaḥ jātam kumāram jātakarma ādinā pitā bhāvayati
translated: That embryo, a woman carries, i.e., she holds it, before birth, prior to the birth.🔽That father, after the birth, after the birth has taken place, nurtures the newborn child, the infant, with the birth rites, etc.

original: sa pitā yadyasmātkumāraṃ janmano 'dhyūrdhvamagre jātamātrameva jātakarmādinā yadbhāvayati /
analyzed: sa pitā yat yasmāt kumāram janmanaḥ dhi ūrdhvam agre jāta mātram eva jātakarma ādinā yat bhāvayati
translated: That father, because he nurtures the newborn child, the infant, with the birth rites, etc., after the birth, immediately after birth.

analyzed: tat ātmānam eva bhāvayati
translated: He nurtures himself.

analyzed: pituḥ ātmā eva hi putra rūpeṇa jāyate
translated: For the father himself is born in the form of the son.

analyzed: tathā hi uktam patiḥ jāyām praviśati hari ityādi
translated: For thus it is said: The husband enters the wife, Hari... and so on.

original: tatkimarthamātmānaṃ putrarūpeṇa janayitvā bhāvayatītyucyate eṣāṃ lokānāṃ santatyā avicchedāyetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: tat kimartham ātmānam putra rūpeṇa janayitvā bhāvayati iti ucyate eṣām lokānām santatyai a vicchedāya iti arthaḥ
translated: For what purpose does he generate himself in the form of the son and nurture him? The meaning is: for the continuity of these worlds, for their non-interruption.

original: vicchidyeranhīme lokāḥ putrotpādanādi yadi na kuryuḥ kecana /
analyzed: vicchidyeran hi ime lokāḥ putra utpādana ādi yadi na kuryuḥ kecana
translated: For these worlds would be interrupted if no one were to produce sons, etc.

original: evaṃ putrotpādanādikarmāvicchedenaiva santatāḥ prabandharūpeṇa vartante hi yasmādime lokāstasmāttadavicchedāya tatkartavyaṃ na mokṣāyetyarthaḥ
analyzed: evam putra utpādana ādi karma avicchedena eva santatāḥ prabandha rūpeṇa vartante hi yasmāt ime lokāḥ tasmāt tad avicchedāya tat kartavyam na mokṣāya iti arthaḥ
translated: Thus, these worlds continue in a series, in the form of a succession, only as long as the acts of begetting offspring, etc. are not interrupted. Therefore, for the non-interruption of that, that should be done, not for liberation. This is the meaning.

original: tadasya saṃsāriṇaḥ kumārarūpeṇa māturudarādyannirgamanaṃ tadretorūpāpekṣayā dvitīyaṃ janma dvitīyāvasthābhivyaktiḥ ////
analyzed: tat asya saṃsāriṇaḥ kumāra rūpeṇa mātuḥ udarāt yat nirgamanam tat retaḥ rūpa apekṣayā dvitīyam janma dvitīya avasthā abhivyaktiḥ
translated: The second birth of this transmigrating soul, in the form of a youth, when it comes out of the mother's womb, is the second manifestation of the stage, in relation to the form of semen.

original: so 'syāyam ātmā puṇyebhyaḥ karmebhyaḥ pratidhīyate /🔽athāsyāyam itara ātmā kṛtakṛtyo vayogataḥ praiti /
analyzed: saḥ sya ayam ātmā puṇyebhyaḥ karmebhyaḥ pratidhīyate  atha asya ayam itaraḥ ātmā kṛtakṛtyaḥ vayaḥ gataḥ praiti
translated: This soul of his is appointed to meritorious deeds.🔽Now, this other soul of his, having done what was to be done, departs at the proper time.

original: sa itaḥ prayann eva punar jāyate /
analyzed: saḥ itas prayan eva punar jāyate
translated: Departing from here, he is born again.

analyzed: tat asya tṛtīyam janma
translated: That is his third birth.

original: asya pituḥ so 'yaṃ putrātmā puṇyebhyaḥ śāstroktebhyaḥ karmabhyaḥ karmaniṣpādanārthaṃ pratidhīyate pituḥ sthāne pitrā yatkartavyaṃ tatkaraṇāya
analyzed: asya pituḥ saḥ yam putra ātmā puṇyebhyaḥ śāstra uktebhyaḥ karmabhyaḥ karma niṣpādana artham pratidhīyate pituḥ sthāne pitrā yat kartavyam tad karaṇāya
translated: This son-soul of his is appointed to meritorious deeds, to the deeds prescribed by the scriptures, for the performance of those deeds, in the place of the father, for the performance of what is to be done by the father.

analyzed: pratinidhīyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that he is appointed in place of the father.

original: tathā ca saṃprattividyāyāṃ vājasaneyake pitrānuśiṣṭaḥ ahaṃ brahmāhaṃ yajñaḥbṛ /u / / /
analyzed: tathā ca saṃprattividyāyām vājasaneyake pitrā anuśiṣṭaḥ aham brahmā aham yajñaḥ
translated: And in the same way, in the Sampratividya of the Vajasaneyins, instructed by his father, I am Brahman, I am the sacrifice (Brh. 4.4.22).

analyzed: ityādi pratipadyate iti
translated: Thus, he attains this and so on.

original: athānantaraṃ putre niveśyātmano bhāramasya putrasyetaro 'yaṃ yaḥ pitrātmā kṛtakṛtyaḥ kartavyādṛṇatrayādvimuktaḥ kṛtakartavya ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: atha anantaram putre niveśya ātmanaḥ bhāram asya putrasya itaraḥ yam yaḥ pitṛ ātmā kṛtakṛtyaḥ kartavyāt ṛṇa trayāt vimuktaḥ kṛta kartavyaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Then, after entrusting his own burden to his son, this other one, who is the father's self, becomes one who has done his duty, freed from the three debts of duty, meaning he has done what must be done.

analyzed: vayaḥ gataḥ gata vayāḥ jīrṇaḥ san praiti mriyate
translated: Having reached old age, being aged, he departs, dies.

original: sa ito 'smātprayanneva śarīraṃ parityajanneva tṛṇajalūkāvad dehāntaramupādadānaḥ karmacitaṃ punarjāyate /
analyzed: saḥ itas smāt prayan eva śarīram parityajan eva tṛṇa jalūkā vat deha antaram upādadānaḥ karma citam punar jāyate
translated: He, even while departing from this world, even while abandoning the body, like a grasshopper, taking up another body created by karma, is born again.

analyzed: tat asya mṛtvā pratipattavyam yat tat tṛtīyam janma
translated: That which is to be attained by him after death, that is the third birth.

original: nanu saṃsarataḥ pituḥ sakāśādretorūpeṇa prathamaṃ janma /
analyzed: nanu saṃsarataḥ pituḥ sakāśāt retaḥ rūpeṇa prathamam janma
translated: Indeed, for one who transmigrates, the first birth is in the form of semen from the father.

analyzed: tasya iva kumāra rūpeṇa mātuḥ dvitīyam janma uktam
translated: The second birth is said to be in the form of a young boy from the mother, just like that.

original: tasyaiva tṛtīye janmani vaktavye pretasya pituryajjanma tattṛtīyamiti kathamucyate /
analyzed: tasya eva tṛtīye janmani vaktavye pretasya pituḥ yat janma tat tṛtīyam iti katham ucyate
translated: When that third birth is to be mentioned, how is it said that the birth of the deceased father is the third?

analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ pitāputrayoḥ aikātmyasya vivakṣita tvāt
translated: This is not a fault, because the identity of the father and son is intended.

original: so 'pi putraḥ svaputre bhāraṃ nidhāyetaḥ prayanneva punarjāyate yathā pitā /
analyzed: saḥ u pi putraḥ sva putre bhāram nidhāya itas prayan eva punar jāyate yathā pitā
translated: That son also, having entrusted the burden to his own son, even while departing from this world, is born again, just like the father.

analyzed: tat anyatra uktam itaratra api uktam eva bhavati iti manyate śrutiḥ pitāputrayoḥ eka ātma tvāt
translated: The Śruti thinks that what is said in one place is said in another also, because the father and the son are of the same nature.

original: evaṃ saṃsarannavasthābhivyaktitrayeṇa janmamaraṇaprabandhārūḍhaḥ sarvo lokaḥ saṃsāramasudre
analyzed: evam saṃsaran avasthā abhivyakti trayeṇa janma maraṇa prabandha ārūḍhaḥ sarvaḥ lokaḥ saṃsāram asudre
translated: Thus, all people, while transmigrating, are immersed in the ocean of worldly existence, having taken the form of the continuity of birth and death through the three manifest states.

original: nipatitaḥ katañcidyadā śrutyuktamātmānaṃ vijānāti yasyāṃ kasyāñcidavasthāyāṃ tadaiva
analyzed: nipatitaḥ katañcid yadā śruti uktam ātmānam vijānāti yasyām kasyāñcid avasthāyām tadā eva
translated: When one knows the Self taught in the Upaniṣads, in some state or other, then alone

analyzed: mukta sarva saṃsāra bandhanaḥ kṛtakṛtyaḥ bhavati iti
translated: one who is freed from all the bonds of worldly existence becomes one who has done his duty.

original: tad uktam ṛṣiṇā garbhe nu sann anv eṣām avedamahaṃ devānāṃ janimāni viśvā /
analyzed: tat uktam ṛṣiṇā garbhe nu san anu eṣām avedam aham devānām janimāni viśvā
translated: This has been said by the sage: Even while in the womb, I knew the births of all the gods.

original: śataṃ mā pura āyasīr arakṣannadha śyeno javasā nir adīyam /
analyzed: śatam mā puraḥ āyasīḥ arakṣan adha śyenaḥ javasā niḥ adīyam
translated: A hundred iron barriers protected me from the front, and I was released by the swift hawk.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

original: garbha evaitac chayāno vāmadeva evam uvāca // / //
analyzed: garbhaḥ eva etat śayānaḥ vāmadevaḥ evam uvāca
translated: Lying in the womb itself, Vāmadeva said this.

analyzed: etat vastu tat ṛṣiṇā mantreṇa api uktam iti āha
translated: This matter has been stated by that sage in a mantra, says (the author).

analyzed: garbhe nu mātuḥ garbhāśaye eva san
translated: In the womb, while in the womb of the mother.

analyzed: nu iti vitarke
translated: Nu (in the mantra) is used in the sense of reflection.

original: anekajanmāntarabhāvanāparipākavaśādeṣāṃ devānāṃ vāgagnyādīnāṃ janimāni janmāni viśvā
analyzed: aneka janma antara bhāvanā paripāka vaśāt eṣām devānām vāc agni ādīnām janimāni janmāni viśvā
translated: By the power of the maturation of meditation over many lifetimes, the births of these gods, such as Agni in the form of speech, and all others,

original: viśvāni sarvāṇyanvavedamahamaho anubuddhavānasmītyarthaḥ śatamanekā bahvyo mā māṃ
analyzed: viśvāni sarvāṇi anvavedam aham aho anubuddhavān asmi iti arthaḥ śatam anekāḥ bahvyaḥ mā mām
translated: I have known all things, i.e. I have understood all things. A hundred, many, many, have not protected me,

analyzed: puraḥ āyasīḥ āyasyaḥ loha mayyaḥ iva abhedyāni śarīrāṇi iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: the iron ones, i.e. the bodies that are indestructible like iron, is the idea.

analyzed: arakṣan a rakṣitavatyaḥ saṃsāra pāśa nirgamanāt adhas
translated: They have not protected, i.e. they have not guarded me from falling down due to not escaping from the bondage of worldly existence.

original: atha śyena iva jālaṃ bhittvā javasā ātmajñānakṛtasāmarthyena niradīyaṃ nirgato 'smi /
analyzed: atha śyenaḥ iva jālam bhittvā javasā ātma jñāna kṛta sāmarthyena niradīyam nirgataḥ smi
translated: Then, like a hawk breaking through a net with speed, with the ability created by the knowledge of the self, I have escaped, i.e. I have come out.

original: aho garbha eva śayāno vāmadeva ṛṣirevamuvācaitat ////
analyzed: aho garbhe eva śayānaḥ vāmadevaḥ ṛṣiḥ evam uvāca etat
translated: Ah! Lying in the womb itself, the sage Vamadeva spoke thus.

original: sa evaṃ vidvān asmāc charīrabhedād ūrdhvam utkramyāmuṣmin svarge loke sarvān kāmān āptvāmṛtaḥ samabhavat samabhavat // / //
analyzed: saḥ evam vidvān asmāt śarīrabhedāt ūrdhvam utkramya amuṣmin svarge loke sarvān kāmān āptvā amṛtaḥ samabhavat samabhavat
translated: He, knowing thus, having gone forth from this body, having ascended to that heavenly world, having obtained all desires, became immortal, became immortal.

translated: That sage Vamadeva, knowing the self as described, having gone forth from this body, from this body imagined by ignorance,

translated: Having become one with the supreme Self, he transcended the lower state, i.e., worldly existence, and attained the state of being the pure Self illuminated by knowledge.🔽Having become one with the supreme Self, he transcended the lower state, i.e., worldly existence, and attained the state of being the pure Self illuminated by knowledge.🔽He attained immortality in his own self, in his own nature, in heaven, like a lamp going out, having attained the state of the unborn, the undying, the immortal, the fearless, the omniscient, the unprecedented, the incomparable, the uninterrupted, the external,

original: prajñānāmṛtaikarase pradīpavannirvāṇamatyagamatsvarge loke svasminnātmani sve svarūpe 'mṛtaḥ samabhavat /
analyzed: prajñāna amṛta eka rase pradīpa vat nirvāṇam atyagamat svarge loke svasmin ātmani sve svarūpe mṛtaḥ samabhavat
translated: which is the nectar of the knowledge named Prajna, having a single taste.

analyzed: ātma jñānena pūrvam āpta kāmatayā jīvan eva sarvān kāmān āptvā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that by the knowledge of the Self, he attained all desires even while living, having attained them earlier.

analyzed: dvirvacanam sa phalasya sa udāhaṇasya ātma jñānasya parisamāpti pradarśana artham
translated: The repetition is to show the completion of the fruitful and illustrated knowledge of the Self.

analyzed: iti prathama adhyāye prathamaḥ khaṇḍaḥ samāptaḥ
translated: Thus ends the first section of the first chapter.

analyzed: dvitīyaḥ adhyāyaḥ samāptaḥ
translated: The second chapter is complete.

analyzed: bahma vidyā sādhana kṛta sarva ātma bhāva phala avāptim vāmadeva ādi ācārya paramparayā śrutyā avadyotyamānām
translated: The attainment of the fruit of the state of all-pervasiveness, which is accomplished by the means of knowledge of Brahman, is being illuminated by the Vedic text through the succession of teachers beginning with Vamadeva,

analyzed: brahma vid pariṣadi atyanta prasiddhām upalabhamānāḥ mumukṣavaḥ
translated: and is well-known in the assembly of knowers of Brahman. Seeing this, the Brahmins who are desirous of liberation and are seeking to know Brahman in the present time,

translated: desiring to turn away from the state of worldly existence characterized by the performance of means and ends, which is impermanent, ask each other,

analyzed: pṛcchanti kaḥ yam ātmā iti katham
translated: Who is this self?

analyzed: kaḥ yam
translated: What is this?

analyzed: ātmā iti vayam upāsmahe
translated: We worship him as the self.

analyzed: kataraḥ saḥ ātmā
translated: Which is that self?

original: yena vā paśyati yena vā śṛṇoti yena vā gandhāñ jighrati yena vā vācaṃ vyākaroti yena vā svādu cāsvādu ca vijānāti // / //
analyzed: yena vā paśyati yena vā śṛṇoti yena vā gandhām jighrati yena vā vācam vyākaroti yena vā svādu ca a svādu ca vijānāti
translated: By which one sees, by which one hears, by which one smells odors, by which one utters speech, by which one experiences what is sweet and unsweet,

original: yamātmānamayamātmeti sākṣādvayamupāsmahe kaḥ sa ātmeti yaṃ cātmānamayamātmeti sākṣādupāsīno vāmadevo 'mṛtaḥ samabhavattameva vayanamapyupāsmahe
analyzed: yam ātmānam ayam ātmā iti sākṣāt vayam upāsmahe kaḥ saḥ ātmā iti yam ca ātmānam ayam ātmā iti sākṣāt upāsīnaḥ vāmadevaḥ mṛtaḥ samabhavat tam eva vayanam api upāsmahe  /
translated: We worship that very self whom we directly worship as the self. Who is that self whom Vamadeva, while directly worshipping as the self, became immortal? We worship that very self.

analyzed: kaḥ nu khalu saḥ ātmā iti
translated: Who indeed is that self?

analyzed: evam jijñāsā pūrvam anyonyam pṛcchatām atikrānta viśeṣa viṣaya śruti saṃskāra janitā smṛtiḥ ajāyata
translated: Thus, having inquired into each other's views, they came to remember the Vedic texts that had been impressed on their minds.

original: 'taṃ prapadābhyāṃ prāpadyata brahmemaṃ puruṣam' 'sa etameva sīmānaṃ vidāryaitayā dvārā prāpadyata' etameva puruṣam /
analyzed: tam prapadābhyām prāpadyata brahma imam puruṣam saḥ etam eva sīmānam vidārya etayā dvārā prāpadyate etam eva puruṣam
translated: They said, He reached this person by his feet, He, having rent asunder this very limit, reached by this door this very person.

original: atra dve brahmaṇī itaretaraprātikūlyena pratipanne iti /
analyzed: atra dve brahmaṇī itaretara prātikūlyena pratipanne iti
translated: Here, two Brahmans are presented as opposed to each other.

analyzed: te ca āsya piṇḍasya ātma bhūte
translated: And they are the self of this very body.

analyzed: tayoḥ anyataraḥ ātmā upāsyaḥ bhavitum arhati
translated: One of them deserves to be the self to be meditated upon.

original: yo 'tropāsyaḥ kaḥ ātmeti viśeṣanirdhāraṇārthaṃ punaranyonyaṃ papracchurvicārayantaḥ /
analyzed: tra upāsyaḥ kaḥ ātmā iti viśeṣa nirdhāraṇa artham punar anyonyam papracchuḥ vicārayantaḥ
translated: Which one is the self to be meditated upon here? In order to determine this, they again asked each other, reflecting.

analyzed: punar teṣām vicārayatām viśeṣa vicāraṇā āspada viṣayā matiḥ abhūt
translated: Again, while they were reflecting, their minds turned to the subject of the special consideration.

analyzed: katham dvevastuni asmin piṇḍe upalabhyete
translated: How? Two things are perceived in this body.

analyzed: aneka bheda bhinnena karaṇena yena upalabhate
translated: By which one perceives through many different kinds of organs.

analyzed: yaḥ ca ekaḥ upalabhyete
translated: And that which is perceived as one.

analyzed: karaṇa antara upalabdha viṣaya smṛti pratisandhānāt
translated: By the recollection and association of the object perceived by a different organ.

original: tatra na tāvadyenopalabhate sa ātmā bhavitumarhati /
analyzed: tatra na tāvat yena upalabhate saḥ ātmā bhavitum arhati
translated: Among them, that by which one perceives cannot be the self.

original: kena punarupalabhata ityucyate yena vā cakṣurbhūtena rūpaṃ paśyati /
analyzed: kena punar upalabhate iti ucyate yena vā cakṣuḥ bhūtena rūpam paśyati
translated: By what, then, is it perceived? It is said: By what has become the eye, one sees form.

analyzed: yena vā śruṇoti śrotra bhūtena śabdam
translated: By what has become the ear, one hears sound.

analyzed: yena vā ghrāṇa bhūtena gandhān ājighrati
translated: By what has become the nose, one smells odors.

original: yena vā vākkaraṇabhūtena vācaṃ nāmātmikāṃ vyākaroti gauraśva ityevamādyāṃ sādhvasādhviti ca /
analyzed: yena vā vāc karaṇa bhūtena vācam nāma ātmikām vyākaroti gauḥ aśvaḥ iti evamādyām sādhu asādhu iti ca
translated: By what has become the organ of speech, one utters speech consisting of names, such as cow, horse, and so on, and good and bad.

original: yena vā jihvābhūtena svādu cāsvādu ca vijānātīti ////
analyzed: yena vā jihvā bhūtena svādu ca a svādu ca vijānāti iti
translated: By what has become the tongue, one experiences what is sweet and what is not sweet.

analyzed: kim punar tat eva ekam anekadhā bhinnam karaṇam iti ucyate
translated: Now, is that very same one instrument said to be divided into many? It is said:

analyzed: yat etat hṛdayam manaḥ ca etat
translated: That which is the heart and that which is the mind,

original: sañjñānam ājñānaṃ vijñānaṃ prajñānaṃ medhā dṛṣṭir dhṛtir matir manīṣā jūtiḥ smṛtiḥ
analyzed: sañjñānam ājñānam vijñānam prajñānam medhā dṛṣṭiḥ dhṛtiḥ matiḥ manīṣā jūtiḥ smṛtiḥ
translated: that is the cognition, the knowledge, the consciousness, the wisdom, the intelligence, the vision, the firmness, the understanding, the thought, the impulse, the memory,

original: saṅkalpaḥ kratur asuḥ kāmo vaśa iti sarvāṇy evaitāni prajñānasya nāmadheyāni bhavanti // / //
analyzed: saṅkalpaḥ kratuḥ asuḥ kāmaḥ vaśaḥ iti sarvāṇi eva etāni prajñānasya nāmadheyāni bhavanti
translated: the determination, the will, the life, the desire, the control - all these are the names of wisdom.

original: yaduktaṃ purastātprajānāṃ reto hṛdayaṃ hṛdayasya reto mano manasā sṛṣṭā āpaśca varuṇaśca hṛdayānmano manasaścandramāḥ /
analyzed: yat uktam purastāt prajānām retaḥ hṛdayam hṛdayasya retaḥ manaḥ manasā sṛṣṭāḥ āpaḥ ca varuṇaḥ ca hṛdayāt manaḥ manasaḥ candramāḥ
translated: As was said before: The heart is the seed of beings. The mind is the seed of the heart. From the mind, the mind is created. From the mind, the moon.

analyzed: tat eva etat hṛdayam manaḥ ca ekam eva tat anekadhā
translated: That very thing is the heart and mind, it is one but manifold.

original: etenāntaḥkaraṇenaikena cakṣurbhūtena rūpaṃ paśyati śrotrabhūtena śṛṇoti ghrāṇabhūtena
analyzed: etena antaḥkaraṇena ekena cakṣuḥ bhūtena rūpam paśyati śrotra bhūtena śṛṇoti ghrāṇa bhūtena
translated: By this single internal organ, which is like the eye, one sees forms, by what is like the ear one hears, by what is like the nose one smells,

original: jighrati vāgbhūtena vadati jihvābhūtena rasayati svenaiva vikalpanārūpeṇa manasā
analyzed: jighrati vāc bhūtena vadati jihvā bhūtena rasayati svena eva vikalpanā rūpeṇa manasā
translated: by what is like the speech one speaks, by what is like the tongue one tastes, by the mind itself in the form of discrimination one discriminates,

analyzed: vikalpayati hṛdaya rūpeṇa adhyavasyati
translated: by what is in the form of the heart one determines.

analyzed: tasmāt sarva karaṇa viṣaya vyāpārakam ekam idam karaṇam sarva upalabdhi artham upalabdhuḥ
translated: Therefore, this one organ, which functions in the domain of all the sense organs, is for the experiencer for the purpose of all experience.

original: tathā ca kauṣītakīnāṃprajñayā vācaṃ samāruhya vācā sarvāṇi nāmānyāpnoti /
analyzed: tathā ca kauṣītakīnām prajñayā vācam samāruhya vācā sarvāṇi nāmāni āpnoti
translated: And thus, for the Kauṣītakins, having mounted speech with wisdom, one obtains all names through speech.

original: prajñā cakṣuḥ samāruhya cakṣuṣā sarvāṇi rūpāṇyāpnoti / ityādi /
analyzed: prajñā cakṣuḥ samāruhya cakṣuṣā sarvāṇi rūpāṇi āpnoti   /
translated: Having mounted wisdom on the eye, one obtains all forms through the eye, and so on.

translated: And in the Vājasaneyaka, it is said, For one sees with the mind, one hears with the mind, for with the heart one knows forms.

analyzed: tasmāt hṛdaya manaḥ vācyasya sarva upalabdhi kara tvam prasiddham
translated: Therefore, it is well known that the heart-mind is the doer of all experience.

original: tadātmakaśca prāṇoyo vai prāṇaḥ sā prajñā yo vai prajñā sa prāṇaḥkauṣī / /
analyzed: tad ātmakaḥ ca prāṇaḥ yaḥ vai prāṇaḥ sā prajñā yaḥ vai prajñā sa prāṇaḥkauṣī
translated: And prāṇa is of the nature of that. That which is prāṇa is wisdom, that which is wisdom is prāṇa. (Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad 3.10)

analyzed: iti hi brāhmaṇam
translated: Thus, O Brāhmaṇa.

translated: And we have said that Prāṇa is a collection of instruments, in the beginning of the dialogue about Prāṇa.

original: tasmādyatpadbhyāṃ prāpadyata tadbrahma tadupalabdhurupalabdhikaraṇatvena guṇabhūtatvānnaiva tadvastu brahmopāsyātmā bhavitumarhati /

translated: Therefore, what is reached by the feet, that is Brahman. Because it is a subordinate factor as the means of perception for the perceiver who has attained it, that object is not fit to be the Brahman to be meditated upon as the self.

original: pāriśeṣyādyasyopalabdhurupalabdhyarthaṃ etasya hṛdayasya manorūpasya karaṇasya vṛttayo vakṣyamāṇāḥ /

translated: By elimination, the one who is the perceiver, for the purpose of perception, the functions of this heart, which is the instrument in the form of mind, will be described.

original: sa upalabdhopāsya ātmāno 'smākaṃ bhavitumarhatīti niścayaṃ kṛtavantaḥ /
analyzed: saḥ upalabdha upāsyaḥ ātmānaḥ smākam bhavitum arhati iti niścayam kṛtavantaḥ
translated: We have concluded that he, the object of perception, is fit to be our self to be meditated upon.

original: tadantaḥkaraṇopādhisthasyopalabdhuḥ prajñārūpasya brahmaṇa upalabdhyarthā yā antaḥkaraṇavṛttayo bāhyāntarvartiviṣayaviṣayāstā imā ucyante /

translated: The functions of the internal organ, which are for the purpose of perceiving Brahman, which is the perceiver residing in the limiting adjunct of the internal organ in the form of wisdom, and which have as their objects external and internal objects, are described as these.

analyzed: saṃjñānam saṃjñaptiḥ cetana bhāvaḥ

analyzed: ājñānam ājñaptiḥ īśvara bhāvaḥ vijñānam kalā ādi parijñānam

analyzed: prajñānam prajñaptiḥ prajña tā
